channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Michael Meyer on Living and Writing ‘In Manchuria’
item.description: The American writer’s new book on China is based on the time he spent in his wife’s childhood village, a region known to people of a bygone era as Manchuria.
item.category: In Manchuria: A Village Called Wasteland and the Transformation of Rural China (Book)
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: At Chinese Political Meetings, the Fashion Is Restraint
item.description: Once a stage for some of China’s most powerful politicians and high achievers to strut the trappings of their success, the sessions have been characterized by conspicuous nonconsumption this year.
item.dc:creator: JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: Li Xiaolin, chief executive of China Power International Development and daughter of former Premier Li Peng, who in the past attracted comment for her designer clothes, adopted a lower-key look for this year's meetings of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Where Beijing’s Trash Is Reborn
item.description: Sim Chi Yin describes the recycling yards on the outskirts of Beijing that she photographed for the launch of the @nytimes Instagram account.
item.dc:creator: SIM CHI YIN
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Observers Extend Monitoring Mission
item.description: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe will extend its observer mission to Ukraine for one year, until March 2016, and may double its size to 1,000 observers, a spokeswoman said Thursday.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Archaeologists Find 300-Year-Old Pretzels. (No Sign of the Beer.)
item.description: Two pretzels unearthed during a dig on the banks of the Danube in Regensburg could be more than 300 years old but are similar to ones available today, archaeologists said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Gunmen Attack State Government’s Headquarters
item.description: Gunmen attacked the headquarters of the South Western State government in Baidoa, killing at least four government soldiers and two civilians, a Somali official said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Villagers Say They Saw Missile Just Before Civilian Jet Was Shot Down
item.description: Villagers in eastern Ukraine have said they saw a missile flying directly overhead just before a Malaysian airliner was shot down last July, providing the most detailed accounts to date.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: American and British Aid Workers Infected With Ebola in Sierra Leone
item.description: The new infections were a reminder that the Ebola crisis that has ravaged West Africa is far from over.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Senator Corker Pushes Obama for Congressional Vote on Iran Deal
item.description: The warning from Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, was the latest twist in an increasingly tense standoff between the White House and congressional Republicans over the potential nuclear accord.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: United Nations’ Reputation Slips as Four-Year War in Syria Drags On
item.description: The U.N. has been unable to offer a path out of a war that has left an estimated 220,000 dead, given rise to vicious jihadists and spread havoc across the region.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian Kurdish refugees seeking shelter last fall in Turkey. Aid agencies trying to help Syrians say they continue to be stymied in their efforts.

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: New Appeal for Detained Reporter
item.description: The Iranian lawyer for Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter incarcerated in Iran for nearly eight months, has requested a five-day release for him starting March 21, the beginning of Iran’s New Year, so he can be with his family.
item.dc:creator: JACOB W. SOTAK

item.title: From the Gates Foundation, Direct Investment, Not Just Grants
item.description: The philanthropic giant is deploying funds and influence into for-profit companies with bright ideas, instead of focusing only on grants to nonprofits.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MAX
item.media:description: A bKash agent in rural Bangladesh. The Gates foundation invested $11 million in bKash, which lets users turn a basic mobile phone into a means of storing and transferring money.

item.title: Monrovia Journal: Ebola, Thief of Rituals, Leaves No Graves to Decorate
item.description: Decoration Day is for sprucing up burial sites and celebrating life, but after 3,000 bodies were cremated because of the Ebola outbreak, Wednesday’s holiday was a somber affair.
item.dc:creator: CLAIR MacDOUGALL
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burial team unloading bodies at a crematorium in Monrovia, Liberia. Because of Ebola, many people accustomed to sprucing up relatives’ graves on a memorial holiday had nowhere to visit.

item.title: Commerzbank of Germany to Pay $1.5 Billion in U.S. Case
item.description: Commerzbank, one of Germany’s largest lenders, was accused of sending tainted money through the American financial system.
item.dc:creator: BEN PROTESS
item.media:description: A branch of Commerzbank in Berlin. Germany’s second-largest lender settled several investigations in the United States.

item.title: Language of Greek Crisis Shifts From Financial Jargon to Humiliation
item.description: With Greece and its European creditors locked in bitter negotiations this week over the terms of the country’s bailout, the politesse of the talks has disintegrated into starkly personal terms.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece, right, and Yanis Varoufakis, the finance minister, have invoked Germany’s Nazi past.

item.title: A Balancing Act as Iraq Claims Gains in Tikrit
item.description: A major step for the Iraqi government in fighting ISIS came with Shiite militias and Iranian military officials in a leading role, which has American officials worried.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Shiite fighters near a suicide bomb attack Thursday on the southern edge of Tikrit, site of an offensive by Iraqi government forces.

item.title: Mercenaries Join Nigeria’s Military Campaign Against Boko Haram
item.description: A foreign force that includes hundreds of South Africans is now fighting the Islamist group, officials said. Separately, the Islamic State accepted Boko Haram’s pledge of allegiance.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: A Moment Atop the World for Bhutan’s Last-Ranked Team
item.description: Crediting the ability of the current generation to watch soccer on TV, Bhutan’s national team won its first World Cup qualifying match, beating Sri Lanka on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: JAMES MONTAGUE
item.media:description: Tshering Dorji, left, with his Bhutan teammates after scoring the lone goal in a 1-0 win over Sri Lanka.

item.title: Japanese Coastal Town Still Struggling to Rebuild From 2011 Tsunami
item.description: Those who want to stay in small northern communities worry they could face more waiting as memories fade and focus turns to the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many of the survivors of the tsunami that devastated Otsuchi, Japan, four years ago live in temporary housing like these prefabricated units on school property.

item.title: British Inquiry Calls for Overhaul of Surveillance Laws but Clears Spy Agencies
item.description: The parliamentary investigation also concluded that laws under which the agencies monitored communications were complex and lacked transparency.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
